awd_titl_txt: Psychological mechanisms through which economic scarcity propels racial prejudice
awd_abstract_narration:
When the U.S. economy experiences significant setbacks, its impact is not limited to the financial realm, nor are the detrimental effects evenly shared across all segments of society. For example, in the recent recession, Black Americans had a decrease in household wealth that was much greater than that of Whites. Although widening disparities that occur during recessions are frequently explained in terms of existing structural inequalities, recent findings by Amy R. Krosch, in collaboration with the investigator David M. Amodio, suggests  a psychological basis for disparities. Their work indicates that perception of economic scarcity affects visual perception processes such that those from minority racial groups are perceived as more stereotypical in appearance, and in turn, as less deserving of resources. Such findings suggest that economic events can threaten intergroup relations and increase discrimination, putting particular groups at acute risk. However, the psychological mechanisms by which these macroeconomic factors affect racial perceptions is not understood. Understanding such mechanisms is essential for developing ways to reduce the effects of economic scarcity on prejudice and discrimination.

The current project focuses on key sociocognitive mechanisms through which perceptions of economic scarcity cause biased visual perceptions of individuals from racial minority groups. In a series of eight experiments, the investigator tests the hypothesis that perceived scarcity induces not only stereotyping, but dehumanization processes as well: reduced tendency to infer uniquely human-like traits and emotions from a face and to neurally encode it as a human face. Experiments test whether these processes directly bias perceivers' visual representations of individuals from racial minority groups, which, in turn, propagates behavioral discrimination. This research builds on both classic and novel theories of how economic factors influence intergroup relations, and it makes innovative use of behavioral, neuroscientific, and psychophysical methodologies to examine the visual processing of race. This research aims to gain crucial knowledge of how economic factors contribute to persisting disparities and provide some direction for how these effects may be mitigated.

por.por_cntn:
During economic downturns, racial minorities are often hit the hardest. This pattern was evident in the expanded employment disparities between Black and White Americans during the 2008 Recession and, recently, in employment and health disparities during the COVID-19 crisis. Although these effects are often attributed to structural factors, our prior work shows that perceptions of scarcity can also enhance prejudice within the individual, leading White Americans to perceive Black people more negatively and thus treat them worse (Krosch & Amodio, 2014; Kroch, Tyler, & Amodio, 2017).

What was not known, however, is why perceptions of scarcity lead to negative visual perceptions of Black people. Without this understanding, it is difficult to predict how scarcity-induced prejudice will be expressed or design effective interventions to mitigate such effects. These issues are particularly pressing given the current worldwide recession, due to COVID-19, and surges in anti-Black violence in America.

Intellectual Merit

The broad goal of this project was to investigate the processes through which scarcity induces negative perceptions of Black people. We proposed and tested the roles of two processes: the activation of Black American stereotypes (Aim 1) and the dehumanization of Black individuals (Aim 2). In a series of experiments with 1620 participants, we found evidence that both processes are engaged under scarcity and contribute to negative perceptions of Blacks.

Stereotyping. In Aim 1, we asked whether perceived economic scarcity elicits negative Black stereotypes and whether these stereotypes evoke more stereotypical visual perceptions of Black faces. In the first experiment, participants who believed resources were scarce in a money allocation task reported stronger explicit stereotypes of Black Americans as hostile and low in socioeconomic status (SES), relative to participants in a control condition.

In a second experiment, we used a method that captures the visual image of a face that a person imagines in their mind (the reverse correlation face classification; Dotsch et al., 2008). We found that the perception of economic scarcity led White participants to visualize Black faces as more stereotypical in appearance, as judged by independent raters, compared with faces produced by participants in a control condition.

In a third experiment, we showed that this effect relates to participant?s implicit stereotypes: those with stronger implicit stereotypes of Black Americans as hostile and poor visualized Black faces in more stereotypical ways?an effect that was enhanced under scarcity for some individuals.

Together, these studies revealed that economic scarcity activates negative stereotypes of Black people and that these stereotypes are transmitted to an individual?s visual perceptions of Black people?perceptions shown to promote discriminatory behavior in our past work.

Dehumanization. In Aim 2, we asked whether the perception of economic scarcity leads Whites to dehumanize Black people in their visual perceptions. In an initial study, we used EEG to measure neural activity in White participants while they viewed and allocated money to Black and White recipients. Among participants who believed resources were scarce, face-sensitive neural activity?originating from occipitotemporal lobe just 170 ms after a face appears?was selectively delayed for Black faces, suggesting that these participants were slower to visually encode Black faces as human ?faces.? This impairment then predicted participants? anti-Black disparities in their money allocations.

We replicated this result in a companion fMRI study: under scarcity, Black faces elected a selective decrease in neural activity in the fusiform gyrus, which supports face encoding, and in the striatum, which supports reward processing, and this pattern again predicted anti-Black bias in money allocations.

A third study, which probed participants? visualizations of Black faces, found that Black faces visualized by participants under scarcity appeared less human to independent raters, both in terms of how alive (vs. inanimate) and uniquely human (vs. animal) they appeared.

A final study, which examined the implications for criminal justice contexts, showed that visualizations of Black faces made under scarcity were judged to be less moral and more deserving of punishment by independent raters, as compared with Black faces visualized in a control condition.

These findings collectively demonstrate that the perception of economic scarcity leads White perceivers to dehumanize Blacks, in both their early neural encoding of faces and their mental representations. Moreover, this effect predicted anti-Black biases in money allocations and judgments of criminality.

Conclusion

These findings support our model of how scarcity effects on White?s perceptions of Black people through stereotype activation and dehumanization. Next, we plan to test interventions designed to reduce stereotyping effects and to humanize Black individuals during decisions made under scarcity.

Broader Impacts

This project provided unique training opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate, post-baccalaureate, masters, and doctoral students, several of whom went on to doctoral programs and professorships in psychology and neuroscience. This project also introduced a new interdisciplinary approach for studying intergroup bias, using neuroscience and visual psychophysics, to advance our understanding of systemic bias and racial prejudice.
